eclipse.junit wrote:
> i have a method createpartcontrol(composite).
>  i dont know how do i test this. and in my test how do i create a 
> composite.
> any idea?


Actually, three!  This is a problem I face a lot writing Eclipse GUI's.  
Every Control must have a Composite parent, but every Composite is a 
Control, leading to a chicken and egg problem.  There's three approaches 
you can take here:

1) The simplest is to run your tests as JUnit Plugin Tests.  This will 
run your tests in the context of a running eclipse instance.  You can 
then programmatically create your View, and test its results, or you can 
embed your Control in the top-level window, the Shell, just to get it 
constructed: 
createPartControl(PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getDisplay().getShell())

2) Booting Eclipse takes a long time, and involves so many framework 
calls that you're rapidly testing 20 times more functionality than you 
really want.  It would be nice to be able to create Controls without 
booting Eclipse, but it's difficult, because it requires linking with 
native libraries.  Thanks to your message, I went out to Google for the 
umpteenth time to see if a smarter person had tackled this question, and 
they have!

http://www.eclipsezone.com/eclipse/forums/t49342.html

3) If by chance you have business logic embedded in your UI, and that's 
what you're testing, do consider the Humble Dialog pattern (just ask 
Google).

Hope this helps.  Share and Enjoy,

    David Saff
